incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

We have implemented mitigations for most users, but are still experiencing delays scheduling new user workloads due to an outage by an upstream provider. We are continuing to investigate ways we can mitigate.
We're still seeing continued degradation, and we're working on further mitigations.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are currently investigating an issue running builds for some users in the Oregon region.

incidents.name: Elevated 502 errors in Oregon

incident_updates.body:
Render RCA - 2023-12-11

# Summary

Starting at 2023-12-11 20:33 UTC a Render customer in the Oregon region was subject to a Distributed Denial of Service \(DDoS\) botnet attack. Render uses Cloudflare to offer DDoS protection and Cloudflare immediately began blocking some but not all of the malicious traffic. The remaining traffic overloaded some components of our infrastructure. The attack ended 15 minutes later and within 8 minutes of that, all of our systems had self-recovered and began serving traffic as normal.

# Impact

This outage impacted infrastructure that serves roughly a quarter of our customers in the Oregon region. The web services for these customers were unable to receive traffic responding with a `5xx` HTTP errors. The total degraded service window was 23 minutes \(2023-12-11 20:33 UTC to 2023-12-11 20:56 UTC\), with the acute period \(when no traffic was being served\) for 11 minutes \(2023-12-11 20:39 UTC to 2023-12-11 20:50 UTC\).

# Root Cause

Our Cloudflare configuration did not fully mitigate a DDoS attack against one of our customers. Additionally, parts of our infrastructure were not able to handle the dramatically increased load.

# Mitigations

In the short term, we leveraged Cloudflare's filtering tool to guard against the resumption of the same attack.

We are also working to improve our system's responsiveness to this class of problem generally. Namely, we will be:

* Working with Cloudflare to better leverage their security tools so that our combined systems can respond more adaptively to attacks of this kind.
* Improving our infrastructure to be more resilient to these scenarios.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our December 11th incident: https://stspg.io/v7ck9pgqrr2x

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
Services in Oregon were partially degraded from 20:36 to 20:54 UTC. We’ve identified the cause of the issue and have taken steps to mitigate it.
We're investigating reports that services in Oregon are serving 502 Bad Gateway errors

incidents.name: Some postgres databases are experiencing downtime

incident_updates.body:
# RCA

# Summary

On Thursday November 9th, multiple databases were restarted across all regions due to unexpected restarts triggered by a code change. This code change caused databases to be unavailable for up to 8 minutes. A concurrent but unrelated bug caused some affected databases in the Ohio region to be down for up to 37 minutes.

## Incident Timeline

# Impact

This incident affected a subset of Point-In-Time Recovery-enabled Postgres instances which experienced an unexpected restart during this time. The event resolved itself between 3 and 8 minutes in each cluster, except for the Ohio region.

In the Ohio region, we were unable to scale up to handle the movement of databases. This extended downtime. We rolled back a separate change to resolve the issues with scale up. All affected databases became available again within 37 minutes. 2 Postgres instances in the Ohio region remained unavailable and had to be manually returned to service by an engineer.

# Root Cause

This downtime was triggered by a code deploy of our database management system. The code change created an errant configuration change to specific database configurations which caused them to unexpectedly restart to pick up the new configuration.

# Mitigations

* We will improve monitoring and alerting to decrease our time to detection.
* We will add additional guard rails to our database management system to prevent unintentional restarts, including those due to configuration changes. We have already developed the feature and are planning its roll out.
* We will improve our database management system to prevent the configuration change of this incident from triggering a restart.
* We will add additional testing to detect restart-triggering changes before we deploy them.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our November 9th incident: https://stspg.io/cx6gz8wqkxpf

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
All affected Postgres databases have recovered
We're seeing recovery for Postgres databases across all regions. We're continuing to investigate
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are currently investigating this issue.

incidents.name: Issues with new services, custom domains, and certificates

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We are continuing to monitor the upstream provider. After the issue is resolved upstream, we will examine and reconcile any affected services on our platform.

We continue to monitor an outage with an upstream provider that is impacting new services, certificates and domains on our platform.

New services can be created, but new custom domains will remain in a 'pending' state. This also affects:
- Delays issuing custom domain certificates
- Traffic to new services will be slower until they can be routed directly to their region

We're tracking an incident with Cloudflare (https://www.cloudflarestatus.com/) that is impacting the ability to issue certificates for custom domains. Newly added custom domains will be showing as 'pending'.

At the moment, we don't believe there is any further impact to our service.

incidents.name: Past deployments being made live

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

The fix was fully deployed as of 4:50pm Pacific. Engineering is re-deploying all affected services in order to ensure that they are running the latest successful deployment as expected. Affected services will see a "Triggered by Render" note for a deployment invoked between 5:00pm and 5:30pm Pacific.

Services that use a Pre-Deploy Command may experience an issue where a previous deploy is made live approximately 2 hours later. This is problematic when multiple deploys take place over a 2 hour period, and suddenly code from multiple deployments back is seen executing again.

For example; if a service was deployed at 11:00am, 11:30am, and 12:15am, then around 1:00pm the 11:00am deployment may be seen again unexpectedly.

This issue would only occur on services that use a Pre-Deploy command after one is configured, and only when multiple deploys within 2 hours take place.

A fix for the past deployment being made live is already complete, and is being deployed.

incidents.name: Large WebSocket messages reported to be failing

incident_updates.body:
# Summary

Render uses Cloudflare Workers as an HTTP proxy layer, for managing caching and cached requests, for all customers. A deploy to our Cloudflare Workers introduced new behavior around WebSocket compression, that mixed compressed and uncompressed messages and caused WebSocket client errors. The regression in behavior was manually reported and then disabled.

# Impact

The regression was active for 17 hours, enabled around 2023-10-04 18:46Z \(11:46a PT\) and disabled at 2023-10-05 12:06Z \(05:06a PT\). Several customers using large messages depended on this behavior and helped report and identify the issue.

# Root Cause

During a deploy to enable additional logging in the Cloudflare Workers, a new Cloudflare feature around WebSocket Compression was enabled and included in that deploy. Cloudflare Workers do offer flags to prevent new features from being enabled, but Render did not specifically block this feature from being enabled.

With the WebSocket Compression feature enabled, new WebSocket connections would attempt to use compression and mix compressed and uncompressed data. Messages over 1MB of data then resulted in WebSocket 1002 or 1009 errors on the client or server.

Once the Render support and engineering was aware of the regression, several production changes were reverted until the Cloudflare Workers deployment was identified as the cause. The previous Cloudflare Workers deployment was then rolled back.

# Mitigations

* Render has disabled the Cloudflare Workers feature around WebSocket Compression for the near-term
* Render has added end to end regression testing around this WebSocket behavior with large messages
* Render is creating an automated test suite, actively testing live WebSocket behavior

Customers making large websocket requests (>1Mib) may have received errors about the message being too large. The cause has been identified and reverted.

Customer impact was between 2023-10-04 1846UTC and 2023-10-05 1206UTC
